Label: infection
Desc: host is infected by a pathogen (viruses, bacteria, fungi, or parasites can all serve as pathogens)

Label: example
Desc: one example of a pathogen is bacteria

Label: example
Desc: members of the eukaryotic domain can be pathogens

Label: example
Desc: viruses are common pathogens but are considered non-living, and lack most components present in eukaryotic and even prokaryotic cells.

Label: kingdom
Desc: most fungi that can cause disease are eukaryotic

Label: contains
Desc: eukaryotes contain a membrane bound nucleus

Label: contains
Desc: a key structure in bacteria is their peptidoglycan cell wall, although there are a few exceptions. Gram postivie organisms have thicker peptidoglycan than gram negatives

Label: contains
Desc: ribosomes are largely conserved within domains. Bacteria have 30s + 50s subunits which combine to make the 70s ribosome

Label: contains
Desc: most eukaryotic cells contain membrane sterols like cholesterol. Bacteria mostly do not with the exception of mycoplasma

Label: contains
Desc: ribosomes are largely conserved within domains. Bacteria have 40s + 60s subunits which combine to make the 80s ribosome. However, mitochondria in eukaryotes have the same ribosome subunits as bacteria

Label: uses
Desc: used as mediator for energy transfer

Label: uses
Desc: used as mediator for energy transfer

Label: uses
Desc: used as mediator for energy transfer

Label: encased
Desc: enclosed by a lipoprotein membrane. Polyunsaturated fatty acids

Label: encased
Desc: enclosed by a lipoprotein membrane. Monounsaturated fatty acids. Phosphatidyl ethanolamine

Label: testing
Desc: can determine what type of bacteria through appearance after staining (purple -> gram-positive, pink -> gram negative, etc.)

Label: type
Desc: Initial carbol fuchsin stain (red) retained after acid-alcohol treatment masking methylene blue counter-stain. Stain retention due to a wax-like nearly impermeable cell wall containing mycolic acid and large amounts of fatty acids, waxes, and complex lipids

Label: appears
Desc: crystal violet-iodine complex is resistant to acetone/alcohol wash due to a thick peptidoglycan wall. Cells retain violet color.

Label: appears
Desc: crystal violet-iodine complex washed out by acetone/alcohol due to a thin peptidoglycan layer. Cells show the pink safranin counterstain

Label: contains
Desc: techoic acids are a common feature of the gram positive cell wall, some are peripheral and others are integral

Label: contains
Desc: lipopolysaccharides are expressed on the surface of the outer membrane

Label: contains
Desc: region between 2 membranes, contains enzymes, peptidoglycan, carriers, and controls access to the cell

Label: encased
Desc: some bacteria are enclosed by a capsule made of mostly polysaccharide (or protein in some cases)

Label: possesses
Desc: bacteria possess circular chromosomes and DNA, and they also contain short circular DNA loops called plasmids

Label: contains
Desc: storage molecules, not membrane enclosed. 1. Volutin: polyphosphate “metachromatic granules” – Corynebacterium. 2. Lipid: poly-beta-hydroxybutyrate-Pseudomonas 3. Carbohydrate: glycogen - oral Streptococci

Label: possesses
Desc: some bacteria possess pili/fimbriae for adherence and conjugation

Label: possesses
Desc: some bacteria possess motile flagella that assist movement and chemotaxis

Label: similar
Desc: cleaning refers to inorganic material and organic while sanitization is more organic

Label: method
Desc: physical methods such as heat through autoclave can result in sterilization

Label: method
Desc: some protein modifying agents can result in sterilization, such as iodine, hydrogen peroxide, ethylene oxide, formaldehyde, and glutaraldehyde

Label: synonym
Desc: disinfection and sanitation both reduce the number of organsims in a location, although disinfection technically clears everything except spores while sanitation might not eliminate all non-spore organisms

Label: method
Desc: disinfection is biocidal but does not eliminate spores

Label: potency
Desc: bacteriocidal substances are more potent than bacteriostatic substances as they kill bacteria or prevent multiplication afterwards

Label: method
Desc: most membrane agents are non-sporicidal and thus belong in the disinfectant class

Label: agent
Desc: biocides are mostly bacteriocidal (but can also be considered bacteriostatic)

Label: method
Desc: heat or filtration are examples of physical biocides

Label: state
Desc: if a surface or organism contains pathogens, they are considered septic

Label: agent
Desc: nucleic acid modifying agents are biocides

Label: agent
Desc: preservatives achieve bacteriostasis by making sure food or other products are not contaminated, or that bacteria cannot multiply within

Label: form
Desc: some bacteria have the ability to form resistant spores

Label: temperature
Desc: mesophilic bacteria prefer a medium temperature to grow

Label: temperature
Desc: psychrophilic bacteria prefer colder temps to grow optimally

Label: temperature
Desc: thermophilic bacteria prefer hotter temperatures to grow optimally

Label: oxygen
Desc: different bacteria have different requirements for oxygen

Label: enzyme
Desc: superoxide is an enzyme in the oxygen metabolism pathway. OBLIGATE ANAEROBES do not have superoxide dismutase

Label: enzyme
Desc: catalase is an enzyme in the oxygen metabolism pathway. AEROBES and FACULTATIVE SPECIES have this enzyme

Label: enzyme
Desc: peroxidase is an enzyme in the oxygen metabolism pathway. FACULTATIVE SPECIES and AEROTOLERANT SPECIES have this enzyme

Label: optimums
Desc: All bacteria associated with the human host (normal flora and pathogens) are: mesophilic heterotrophic chemosynthetic

Label: energy
Desc: different bacteria prefer different energy sources

Label: biproduct
Desc: respiration produces different molecules as byproducts

Label: energy
Desc: organisms that undergo aerobic respiration make use of oxygen as the final electron acceptor through glycolysis, the citric acid cycle, and finally through the electron transport chain. Obligate aerobes have more efficient electron transport chains compared to facultative anaerobes

Label: energy
Desc: use some of the pathways of aerobic respiration, but uses other electron acceptors such as NO3

Label: energy
Desc: anaerobic bacteria undergo fermentation through converting glucose to pyruvate to lactate or other end products

Label: result
Desc: nutrients provide resources for bacterial growth

Label: measures
Desc: counting direct cells is a simple method but can be time consuming and does not count only live cells

Label: measures
Desc: viable cell method counts live cells but only those that can form colonies

Label: measures
Desc: sectrophotometry is quick but also counts dead cells

Label: measures
Desc: counts live cells and is used industrially to find optimums.

Label: spastic

Label: labile

Label: flaccid

Label: cause

Label: obligate anaerobe
Desc: hyperbaric treatment can reduce growth and production of alpha toxin. Also contributes to angiogenesis

Label: alpha toxin, theta toxin, others
Desc: lecithinase. It is the alpha toxin that is responsible for much of the tissue destruction seen in the myonecrosis associated with gas gangrene, and is another example of an localized infection with systemic toxemia. This cytotoxin is associated with increased vascular permeability, massive hemolysis and bleeding, tissue destruction, hepatic toxicity, and myocardial dysfunction (bradycardia, hypotension). Shock and renal failure occur rapidly, within a few days of onset. theta toxin causes minor hemolytic toxin, creates double zone of hemolysis (alpha is outer while theta is inner), Four other toxins which are involved in infections caused by this organism are hemolysin, DNase, hyaluronidase, and collagenase. These toxins cause lysis or destruction of red blood cells, DNA, hyaluronic acid, and collagen, respectively, leading to tissue destruction and necrosis.

Label: performs
Desc: double zone of hemolysis formed by theta and alpha toxins

Label: cause
Desc: late onset, warmed meat dishes, enterotoxin is heat labile and results in diarrhea without fever or vomiting. Ingestion of preformed toxin results in more rapid onset of cramps and diarrhea (like a superantigen). No fever or vomiting
